passages.text: Sizable Platforms opportunity underap:preciated, embedding Wise deeper into the cross- border money network
WISEa.L 12m Price Target: 1,550p Price: 1,070p Upside: \(44.9\%\)

We reiterate our Buy rating (on CL) on Wise and raise our 12m PT to 1,550p (from 1,400p). We assess Wise's Platforms business through 2040, which we view as a large and attractive opportunity that the market currently underappreciates, and we believe Wise has reached an inflection within its pipeline with recent key wins. Our long- term upside scenario, which assumes a faster ramp of volume growth for Wise Platform than mid- term guidance and the addition of new partners, implies a near doubling in the share price from current levels.

We see the Platforms opportunity as potentially significantly accretive to our base case group earnings over 2026- 30E, with our long- term upside scenario implying: (1) c.13% accretion to group volumes; and (2) c.25% uplift on average to underlying PBT, reflecting cost savings coupled with the operating leverage inherent in Wise's business model. These characteristics underpin the durability of Wise's growth in our view, and in our base case, we feel confident Wise Platform could represent 10% of group volumes by 2030E (in line with guidance). However, we see upside risks to this, and our long- term upside scenario implies 23%/33% of group volumes by 2030/2040E. In our base case, we are ahead of Visible Alpha Consensus Data by 6- 19% on 2028- 30E underlying income and 7- 12% on underlying PBT. The upside scenario would land us significantly ahead, at 14- 29% and 36- 45% respectively.
WiseConnect in San Francisco on 10th September, a key customer event focused on Wise Platforms, which should

Wise Platform currently represents c.4% of Wise's FY25 cross- border volumes, however the company expects to grow to \(10\%\) over the medium term (implying a volume CAGR of 2X the rest of the business) and \(>50\%\) over the long term, underpinning Wise's target to potentially move 'trillions' of volume. In our view, Wise has reached an inflection within its pipeline with recent key wins such as Nubank, Standard Chartered and Morgan Stanley proof points that Wise Platform is being appreciated by large banks and that further contracts should follow. As Wise increases the number of large partners on its Platform, we believe the network effect will become stronger, helping to scale faster and deepen its competitive advantage. Lastly, the competitive landscape remains dynamic, particularly as it relates to Stablecoins amid a backdrop of greater clarity on the regulatory environment; however, we continue to see a limited impact in the near term on Wise's business given Wise has built one of the lowest cost networks for moving money globally.

Wise Platform enables legacy banks, digital banks and online digital & SaaS players to use Wise's API to send customer payments via Wise's network while these customers remain in the bank's/SaaS platform's own app. Wise Platform addresses three key inefficiencies in cross- border transactions: 1) slow payment speeds and a high cost base; 2) lack of transparency on pricing; 3) customer churn and client growth challenges.

3 main customer segments with legacy banks representing majority of global volumes Wise Platform partners fit into three broad segments: 1) Legacy banks, 2) Digital banks and 3) Online digital/ SaaS vendors. To date, the majority of Platform growth has been from early adopter Digital banks such as Monzo and NuBank which focus on lower cost, fast and convenient cross- border payments as an incentive for their own customers to switch from traditional banks. Online players and SaaS vendors (e.g. Agoda, Deel and Xero) use Wise Platform to integrate financial services as they are not licensed to process payments. For example, Xero Pay with Wise uses the Wise Platform to provide a bill payment feature that enables businesses to pay their suppliers through Xero.

The majority of global cross- border volume, c. \(90\%\) , is conducted via legacy banks, and this customer base represents the greatest opportunity for growth long term. While Wise has partnerships with legacy banks dating back to 2021, we believe the company is reaching an inflection point within its customer pipeline with several new partnership announcements over the past year including Nubank (Ultravioleta customers), Morgan Stanley (corporate payments) and recently UniCredit, Wise's first major European bank partner.

Complex systems integration between a partner and Wise can take several months to years, such as the Standard Chartered partnership, but for digital banks such as Monzo, Wise has been able to integrate its API solutions in a matter of weeks. Our conversations with customers and partners at a recent Wise event (see our note here) support our view that the value proposition that Wise offers has become compelling enough for Legacy Tier 1 and 2 banks to consider, as it has been an area in which banks having historically under invested in the technology infrastructure and so, have experienced greater churn of customers over recent years to the digital tech players.

The G20 cross- border initiative (Exhibit 1) started by the FSB in 2020 aims to bring greater speed, increase access and transparency, and lower cost for cross- border transactions across wholesale, retail and remittance by 2027. Specifically, it aims to reduce the cost of cross- border money transfers to \(1\%\) of the transaction value on average with a single corridor fee capped at a maximum of \(3\%\) by 2030. For remittances specifically, according to the World Bank's 3Q24 Worldwide Remittances Prices report, banks remain the most expensive type of service provider, with an average cost of

\(13.64\%\) of the transaction value, more than two times the global average cost of \(6.62\%\) . While half of the 15 designated actions under the initiative have been implemented, tangible actions on the part of end users have yet to happen and significant progress will be needed to improve the user experience across all payment market segments according to the FSB. We expect such programmes to drive greater collaboration across the ecosystem, with Wise a potential beneficiary.

Overall, the company has highlighted the Platform segment as a key area of growth. Currently \(c.4\%\) of volumes are derived from Wise Platform and the company guides for this to grow to \(10\%\) in the medium term (implying a volume CAGR \(2x\) vs. the rest of the business) and \(>50\%\) over the long term.
Exhibit 1:The G20 cross-border initiative should help drive legacy players to modernize their payment systems G20 cross-border targets

G20 cross-border initiativeWholesale paymentsRetail paymentsSpeed75% within 1 hour, rest within 1 business dayAccessMin. 1 option per payment corridorAll end user to have at least 1 option90% to have access to electronic remittancesTransparencyMinimum defined list of informationCostGlobal average of 1%Global average of 3% (2030)
Cost is as a \(\%\) of the transaction value
Source: Financial Stability Board

Wise has invested £3bn in its technology and infrastructure since its founding with £2bn committed to expanding its technology leadership and roadmap. Wise's global single tech- stack forms the backbone of its Platform offering, which according to the company enables it to scale and drive superior unit economics which result in lower prices for end users across 160 countries in 40 currencies. It has direct connectivity to six local payment systems (UK, Hungary, EU, Philippines, Singapore and Australia) with at least two more countries (Brazil and Japan) being rolled out in the near term. These direct connections remove intermediaries in the payments flow and according to Wise reduce transaction costs by c.9x and facilitate transaction times in as quickly as under 20 seconds. At the group level, \(46\%\) of transactions are through direct connections. Wise highlights that \(65\%\) of transactions are settled in under 20 seconds and \(95\%\) of payments are completed within 24 hours. The company has been leveraging Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) for the past eight years for predicting liquidity needs and trading volumes as well as to power its proprietary financial crime prevention engine.

Overall, we believe Wise has built a highly specialized platform and has the financial flexibility to continue to invest all of its budget in this. Banks, on the other hand, need to balance investments in cross- border capabilities alongside a multitude of other competing interests and so may find it difficult to replicate Wise's infrastructure. Therefore integrating their banking applications beyond the back- end infrastructure with Wise offers a compelling option.

Within Platforms, Wise prices its offering to be profitable from inception, however its units economics largely differ from its direct business (B2C) in two main ways: (1) Lower take rate; and so (2) Lower cost of sales. We show an illustrative example (Exhibit 7) of the unit economics for the Platform vs direct B2C business. We caveat that the actual unit economics may significantly differ from what we present depending on a number of factors discussed in detail below:

FX corridor: The cross- border take rate Wise applies significantly varies by FX corridor. For the group, we assume 57bps (personal cross border take rate as of 1Q26). As mentioned below for scaled FX corridors across USD/GBP/EUR, which we estimate account for c. \(40 - 45\%\) of Wise's overall volumes, we estimate a take rate of 20- 25bps. This is primarily driven by Wise's direct connections allowing it to bypass intermediaries, providing instant payments and ultimately driving down costs.

Volume tiered pricing: We believe Wise operates a volume tiered pricing model whereby small discounts are offered as customers ramp their volumes processed. While these are variable, we don't expect it to be significant given Wise is already very competitive on pricing, and we estimate these can dilute the cross- border take rate by c.1- 5bps. We expect the majority of partners to ramp their share of volumes processed by Wise over time, however we note some partnerships may include contractual time period volume ramp up terms.

Platform partner revenue share agreements: Wise operates a revenue sharing agreement with partner banks whereby Wise achieves a cost saving (c.10bps) when acquiring customers through partners, primarily from lower onboarding costs (customer support, verification, KYC) and from lower customer acquisition costs (marketing). These cost savings are passed back to banking partners as a revenue share.
Revenue recognition: We expect Wise to accrue revenue share monthly for each partner. However actual payment may differ based on the contractual terms (e.g. monthly or quarterly).

Platform partner additional mark- up: While Wise applies a certain take rate (48bps in the illustrative example), the Platform partner has full control on the final fee charged to the end customer. We expect this to vary due to the partner banks' own cost of sales, with Digital Banks able to offer a mark up broadly in line with Wise's direct business (e.g. Monzo). For simplicity in the illustration below, we assume the mark- up charged by the platform equates to Wise's direct business.

Re- investment of cost savings: We show two scenarios: (1) All cost savings are re- invested back into business; and (2) Wise is unable to re- invest all the cost savings. Given Wise's strict requirement on ROI, criteria of \(20\%\) IRR and \(
below in scenario 2, we assume Wise is unable to re- invest \(30\%\) of savings efficiencies, thereby generating accretion to its EBITDA margin.
Exhibit 7: Illustration of Platform unit economics For illustrative purposes only

bpsDirect B2CPlatformPlatform cross-border take rateNM57Platform partner mark-upNM10Wise cross border take rate5747Total costs4131Wise share of cost saving010Scenario 1:Underlying adj. EBITDA1613margin28%28%Scenario 2:Cost savings unable to re-invest3Underlying adj. EBITDA1616margin28%35%
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Over the medium term to long term (c.5+ years), we expect Platforms to represent \(10\%\) of total volumes by 2030 (in line with company guidance) and \(17\%\) by 2040. However, our scenario analysis suggests upside risk to the \(10\%\) of volume guidance as we believe there is sufficient headroom to drive a greater rate of growth within the current existing Platform partners, and we see an upside risk from adding new Platform partners. In our view, Wise has reached an inflection within its pipeline with recent key wins such as Nubank, Standard Chartered and Morgan Stanley proof points that Wise Platform is being appreciated by large banks and further contracts should follow. As Wise increases the number of large partners on its Platform, we believe the network effect will become stronger, helping to scale faster and deepen its competitive advantage. Despite Platforms having a lower take rate than the group, we believe the segment should drive meaningful EBITDA accretion given the strong operating leverage inherent in Wise's business model.
We consider three scenarios:

1) Base Case: Assuming solely of a ramp up of existing Platform partners  
2) Mid-term upside scenario: Assuming a faster ramp of existing Platform partners to 2030E  
3) Long-term upside scenario: Assuming faster ramp of existing Platform partners + future partner wins to 2040E
Exhibit 8: There has been a number of new partner announcements over the past 12-18 months Timeline of Platform partner announcements
Source: Company data, compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

In our Base case, we model Wise's current largest Platform partners to assess the wallet share ramp that would be required to meet the company's mid- term guidance of Platforms representing \(10\%\) of total volumes. In all three scenarios, we do not specifically model the Morgan Stanley partnership due to the complex enterprise offering. Wise operates a 'land and expand' strategy where the initial win involves a small amount of volumes as the partner experiments across certain geographies or clients and then gradually ramps and expand wallet share. Our assumptions are detailed below (Exhibit 11):

- Wallet share penetration: We assume Wise currently has \(c.2\%\) wallet share on average across Platform partners and forecast modest incremental wallet share expansion of c.2 percentage points per year. We assume a wallet share ceiling of \(25\%\) per Platform partner (maximum number of active customers who use FX capabilities of the total customer base). Overall, our Platform FX active customer base grows at a \(c.45\%\) 2025-30E CAGR.

- Volume per customer: We take a conservative VPC of c.£750, representing a \(c.90\%\) discount to Wise's Personal VPC (FY25), and assume growth in line with the IMF's forecasts for global inflation over the mid term \((+3\%)\) . We expect the Platform business to be largely lower ticket VPC customers.
- Cross border take rate: We model a c.1-1.5bp per annum decrease as Wise continues to scale its FX flows and put through sustainable price cuts.
- Gross up factor: We apply a \(10\%\) gross up factor to account for other partners on Wise Platform.
- Cross-border TAM: We expect the overall cross-border TAM to grow at a \(c.4\%\) 2025-40 CAGR.
- Platforms as % of total volume: We derive \(c.4\%\) in 2025 (as indicated by company) growing to \(10\% /17\%\) by 2030/40E.
Exhibit 11: Base Case assumptions
Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Mid- term upside scenario: Faster ramp up of wallet share within existing Platform partners to 2030EHere we consider a mid- term upside scenario to 2030. We model a faster ramp of wallet share capture vs our Base Case as we believe Platform partners are likely to expand their usage of the Wise infrastructure across more FX corridors and segments of its customer base over several years. We assume an incremental wallet share capture of c.5 percentage points per year (vs c.2pp in the Base Case) until 2030 resulting in our Platform FX active customer base growing at a c.73% 2025- 30E CAGR. This scenario adds 5%- 14% to our 2026- 30E total volume estimate relative to our Base Case. Given the greater volumes, we assume a modestly higher cross- border take rate decline (c.1- 2bps per year), which puts our underlying income estimates 3- 8% higher than our Base Case across 2026- 30. The higher revenues, combined with higher margin flow- through assuming a contribution margin of 30% for Platforms revenues (same as in the Base Case), results in underlying PBT accretion of 6- 14% to our 2026- 30 Base Case estimates. Overall, in this upside scenario, Platforms represent 20% of total volumes in 2030E (vs 10% in our Base Case).
Exhibit 12: In our Mid-term upside scenario, Nubank and Itau grow at the fastest rate given their relatively larger retail customer bases...
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 14: We see upside risks to Wise Platform mid-term volume guide Sensitivity of Platform volume as \(\%\) of total volumes in 2030E
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

In this scenario, we look at the long- term upside potential out to 2040. We build on the upside scenario above and assume that Wise both ramps faster wallet share with current Platform partners and wins future Platform partners. We believe as Wise Platform scales with existing partners, this is likely to create a 'network effect' for other banks and players to use Wise's solution. Our assumptions are detailed below (Exhibit 15):

Existing Platform partners: We model Wise ramping to maximum wallet share capture of \(25\%\) by 2030E (same assumptions as in the prior scenario), after which we flat- line wallet share through 2040E.
New Platform partners: We conduct a top- down approach of the global adult banking population and assume c. \(20\%\) will require FX capabilities. We estimate that currently Wise has \(

see a \(4 - 10\%\) increase to our underlying income estimates across 2026- 30. The higher revenues, combined with higher margin flow- through, results in underlying PBT accretion of \(12 - 31\%\) across our 2026- 30 estimates. Overall, we see a number of factors that pose upside risk to our estimates: (1) scale of further new Platform partners; (2) the speed of ramp within each Platform partner; (3) rate of re- investment Wise deploys. Furthermore, (4) while we conservatively focus on the global personal cross- border TAM opportunity, we note long- tail upside risk if Wise establishes a foothold in the SMB and corporate market (f29trn or \(90\%\) of the global cross border TAM).

The main downside risks we see to our view on the Platform opportunity are: (1) Slower ramp period per partner; (2) Lower ticket volume per customer than expected; (3) Higher- than- expected reduction in cross- border fees; (4) Greater costs associated with building out Platform capacity; and (5) Greater competition from disruptive technologies that reduces the incentive for banks to partner with Wise.

As of December 2024, Wise have been partnered with Morgan Stanley, the first US investment bank to implement Wise's white- label Platforms infrastructure to facilitate foreign exchange international settlements capabilities for its corporate customers (large enterprises). Our understanding is that the initial scope of this partnership focuses on FX settlement delivery of the transaction instead of the FX conversion and for a small subsection of the wider customer base. As with most Platform partnerships, Wise operates a 'land and expand' strategy and will potentially expand the offering to more customers with Morgan Stanley and across more currency pairs.

We do not model the Morgan Stanley partnership in our scenarios above as we believe the volume opportunity under the partnership is limited in the short term. Firstly, the partnership will not contribute to cross- border volumes in the short term given Wise only currently handles the settlement and so will book it as 'other revenue'. However, we believe this partnership is a further upside risk to our cross- border volume estimates as the scope of the partnership expands. Secondly, we expect the net take rate to be lower for this partnership compared to other Platform wins given the lower liquidity required for FX settlement compared to conversion.
Exhibit 24: Illustrative FX payment cycle under Morgan Stanley Platform partnership
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Over the past few months, we have seen a resurgence in the debate about the impact of Stablecoins in payments, especially for cross- border transactions and remittance, amidst a backdrop of greater clarity around the regulatory environment with the recently passed GENIUS Act in the US and MiCA in the EU (we highlight our US Payments & Banks team's deep dive into Stablecoins: Assessing the opportunities for Stablecoin adoption across financial services and fintech). Initial investor concern largely stemmed from the inefficiencies of cross- border payments: high costs, opaque fees, slow settlement and limited operating hours with the idea that Stablecoins could be a way to bypass legacy rails for faster, cheaper remittances with near real- time settlement and 24/7 operability. Having said that, we continue to see in the near term a limited impact to Wise's business given Wise has built one of the lowest cost networks for moving money globally.

Wise has built a significant competitive advantage around price by driving down fees and improving speed, with current group cross- border take rate at \(0.52\%\) (as of 1Q26) and settling \(65\%\) of transactions in under twenty seconds. However, in Wise's most developed and scaled corridors such as GBP, USD and EUR (representing \(40 - 45\%\) of total volume), we estimate the average cross- border take rate to be between \(0.20 - 0.25\%\) , and excluding the markup it has very low unit costs. While Stablecoins may provide an increase in speed, we do not see Stablecoins as a near- term solution for many of the structural drivers of costs in cross- border payments such as 1) FX conversion/ off- ramp costs and 2) regulatory compliance and licensing. Here, we believe that user experience, local licensing expertise, KYC, fraud prevention and FX conversion will remain the primary points of differentiation in this space. In this context, the advantage of Stablecoins to the broader developed market corridors appears limited relative to Wise's current performance levels.

While we believe Wise may be well insulated in developed market corridors, we acknowledge that in certain emerging market corridors, characterized by high illiquidity and inflation, Stablecoins may have some use cases where there is demand for dollar access outside of the US. The real- time, 24/7 settlement capabilities of Stablecoins have the potential to accelerate digitization trends in emerging markets, where cash usage is high and current card penetration is low, and ultimately reduce frictions in payments in these corridors. Given much of the costs in consumer remittances stem from the use of cash in emerging markets, Stablecoins may drive down both consumer (payment cost) and money transmitter costs (settlement risk, on/off- ramp fees). However, we note Stablecoins will likely require an off- ramp in fiat currency which would erode a large portion of the cost savings. Additionally, a significant portion of consumers receive remittances in cash, further reducing potential cost savings, unless both endpoints are

natively digital and Stablecoin- accepting which would require a long- term structural shift in consumer adoption. Without broad- based merchant and customer acceptance of Stablecoins, users will continue to rely on intermediaries and on/off- ramps, which reintroduces the fees and frictions that Stablecoins are meant to avoid.

Overall, we believe Wise's global single tech stack coupled with its scale advantages in KYC/AML and local licensing expertise have allowed it to build a platform that yields competitive fees and a best- in- class user experience. In addition to providing the lowest cross- border pricing, Wise delivers further value through the Wise account which gives customers access to additional features including multi- currency accounts, the ability to earn interest on balances (which currently Stablecoin is restricted), a global debit card and access to investment assets via BlackRock. In our view, this broader product suite positions Wise as more than just a low- cost payments provider, but as a differentiated option for consumers seeking a comprehensive, international financial platform. We view the recent Platform wins with major banks as supportive to our thesis that Wise's infrastructure is strongly competitively placed. In emerging market regions that may be exposed to higher Stablecoin adoption in the long term, for example Platform partners in the LATAM and APAC regions, we believe Wise has the tech capabilities to tailor its product offering to evolving consumer demands.
Exhibit 25: Wise has diversified revenue by region with strong exposure to developed markets Revenue by region as of FY25
Source: Company data

Our Platforms Bull Case scenarios suggest upside risk to guidance, giving us greater confidence in our outer year volume growth assumptions. As a result, we raise our FY28- 30 volume/underlying income estimates by \(2 - 4\% /1 - 3\%\) . Looking near term to FY2026, we modestly raise our total underlying income growth to \(18.0\%\) yoy ex- fx (previously \(17.5\%\) ) and raise our underlying gross margins to reflect greater cost saving efficiencies. However, we expect Wise to undertake greater levels of investments across the business both in engineering and sales capacity/marketing to capture the significant market opportunities, particularly in Platforms. As a result, we raise our total admin expenses to \(c.21\%\) yoy growth over the forecasted period. Overall, while our FY26- 27 underlying PBT estimates decrease by \(1\%\) to \(3\%\) , our estimates increase by \(2\%\) to \(5\%\) across FY28- 30 as we reflect a greater margin contribution from Platforms.

Our reverse DCF analysis (Exhibit 30), where we flex volume growth and hold margins flat from 2030E, all else equal, suggests that the market underestimates Wise's long- term growth potential. We believe the market is discounting low teens sales growth for the company (2026- 36E) vs GSe of c.16%, which we view as undemanding.
Exhibit 30: Assuming flat margins from 2030E onwards implies the market is discounting low teens % sales growth in the longer term Wise reverse DCF analysis

Other than macroeconomic risk resulting in weaker consumer spending and remittance trends, the main downside risks we see to our earnings forecasts, price target and view for Wise are:

Slower- than- expected pace of shift to digital cross- border payments: While the remittance market has accelerated towards digital cross- border payments, a stagnation in digital adoption in certain markets could pose a risk for Wise.

Slower ramp period per partner: While we have assumed Wise reaches maximum penetration of each partner in a 5- year ramp period upon signing, we note actual ramp may differ partner to partner depending largely on the simplicity of integration and any contractual requirements.

Execution on growth/growing pains: Wise is a high growth fintech, and operational execution remains the key tenet of delivery of growth. The company may experience growing pains as it expands into new products and geographies. Additionally, the company may incur higher than expected costs in order to invest in capacity.

Competition: While we see Wise as a best- in- class company in the cross- border payments industry, we acknowledge that the competitive landscape remains dynamic, leaving space for newcomers to disrupt the market. The growing interest in Stablecoins potentially may disrupt the existing cross border payments rails, especially with increased regulatory clarity (GENIUS Act, MICA). A change in consumer adoption towards using Stablecoin as a method of send/receiving money and for travel use- cases could erode some of Wise's differentiation and reduce the incentive of potential Platform customers to partner.

Regulatory risks: Wise competes in a highly regulated market in which it requires licenses to operate in many of its jurisdictions to facilitate cross- border money movement. Furthermore, in some markets the company relies on partnerships with other vendors. Changes in the regulatory environment, such as licensing requirements, greater KYC/AML scrutiny and compliance checks could weigh on costs, add more complexity to cross- border payment processing and thus weigh on revenue growth and margins.

We, Mhmd Mwa, Dehka Agaal, Uair Merhant, Pukit Gubotra and Aham Haouach, heey certiy that ll f the views expressed in this report acurately refect our personal views about the subject company or companies and its or their securities. We also certify that no part of our compensation was, is or will be, directly or indirectly, related to the specific recommendations or views expressed in this report.
Unless otherwise stated, the individuals listed on the cover page of this report are analysts in Goldman Sachs' Global Investment Research division.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.
